title: 108_s1451
content: The Act is titled the "Runaway, Homeless, and Missing Children Protection Act." It includes amendments to the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act, specifically changing Section 302 regarding findings. The Congress finds that youth who are homeless or run away from home without parental permission are at risk of serious health and behavioral problems. They lack resources for care and may live on the street, creating law enforcement issues. These young people urgently need temporary shelter and linguistically appropriate services. The Federal Government has a responsibility to address this interstate problem. The Federal Government must develop a national reporting system to address the urgent need for temporary shelter and services for runaway youth and homeless youth. These services should include preventive and aftercare services, emergency shelter, extended residential shelter, and street outreach services. Additionally, these youth require opportunities to complete high school, learn job skills, and secure employment for a successful transition to adulthood. To address the needs of runaway and homeless youth, improved coordination between Federal programs is necessary for a long-term strategy. This includes providing opportunities for education, job skills, and employment for a successful transition to adulthood. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to change the heading to "Basic Center" and include testing for sexually transmitted diseases at the request of youth. An obsolete provision relating to certain allotments is repealed. SEC. 104. Repeal of obsolete provision relating to certain allotments. Section 311(b) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to remove paragraph (3) and redesignate paragraph (4) as paragraph (3). SEC. 105. Eligibility provision. Section 312(a) is amended to replace "juveniles" with "youth". SEC. 106. Recognition of state law relating to capacity limitation on eligible runaway and homeless youth centers. SEC. 105. Eligibility provision amended to replace "juveniles" with "youth". SEC. 106. Recognition of state law regarding capacity limitations on eligible runaway and homeless youth centers. SEC. 107. Maternity group homes. SEC. 107. Maternity group homes are added to the eligibility criteria of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act, providing pregnant or parenting youth with supervised living arrangements and parenting skills training. Maternity group homes offer pregnant or parenting youth a supervised living arrangement to learn parenting skills and promote long-term economic independence for the well-being of their children. Limited extension of 540-day shelter eligibility period for youth under 18 years old in a program under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. Youth can remain in the program until their 18th birthday or 180 days after the end of the 540-day period. Part A plan coordination assurances are also addressed. SEC. 109 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to involve McKinney-Vento school district liaisons in providing educational services to runaway and homeless youth. SEC. 110 addresses Part B plan coordination agreements. SEC. 110 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to include coordination with McKinney-Vento school district liaisons for educational services. SEC. 111 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to develop a plan for proper referral of homeless youth to various services. SEC. 112 focuses on coordinating programs. SEC. 112 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to ensure coordination of programs and services for homeless youth by consulting the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 113 clarifies grant authority for activities under this title, and SEC. 114 makes a technical amendment relating to demonstration projects. SEC. 113 clarifies grant authority for activities under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. SEC. 114 makes a technical amendment relating to demonstration projects, SEC. 115 repeals an obsolete provision, SEC. 116 sets an age limit for homeless youth seeking shelter, and SEC. 117 authorizes appropriations. SEC. 117 authorizes appropriations for the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act, specifying funding amounts for fiscal years 2004 to 2008 and adjusting the allocation percentages for parts A and B. SEC. 118 requires a report on strategies to end youth homelessness within 2 years. SEC. 119 calls for a study on housing services and strategies. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the United States Interagency Council on Homelessness, must submit a report to Congress on strategies to end youth homelessness within 2 years. Additionally, a study will be conducted on housing services and programs funded under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to assess long-term housing outcomes for youth after exiting the program and to identify models and strategies to prevent future homelessness. SEC. 120. RESTRICTION ON USE OF FUNDS. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to restrict the use of funds for distributing sterile needles for illegal drug injection. TITLE II--AMENDMENTS TO MISSING CHILDREN'S ASSISTANCE ACT. Section 402 is amended to update findings. The Congress acknowledges the grave danger faced by abducted children, the risks of physical harm and exploitation, the lack of resources for search efforts, the need for cooperation among law enforcement agencies, and the role of the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children as a national resource center. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children plays a crucial role in coordinating efforts with various law enforcement agencies to find missing children and prevent child victimization. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children collaborates with various agencies to locate missing children and prevent child victimization. It operates a network connecting with missing children clearinghouses in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Scotland Yard, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, INTERPOL headquarters, and others to share information instantly with law enforcement nationwide and globally. The Missing Children's Assistance Act is amended to authorize appropriations for the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children until 2008. This is part of the reauthorization of programs under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act.
